articles.headline: Terror Suspect Brought to U.S. for Trial, Breaking From Trump Rhetoric
articles.snippet: Attorney General Jeff Sessions has adamantly favored holding suspects in Guantánamo Bay. That rhetoric is meeting the reality of fighting terrorism in 2017.
articles.abstract: Attorney General Jeff Sessions has adamantly favored holding suspects in Guantánamo Bay. That rhetoric is meeting the reality of fighting terrorism in 2017.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The Trump administration has brought a man suspected of belonging to Al Qaeda to the United States to face trial in federal court, backing off its hard-line position that terrorism suspects should be sent to the naval prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, rather than to civilian courtrooms.
articles.byline: By Rebecca R. Ruiz, Adam Goldman and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Hard Questions for a Company at the Center of the Opioid Crisis
articles.snippet: McKesson, the nation’s largest drug distributor, will be grilled about executive pay and controlled substances at its annual meeting on Wednesday.
articles.abstract: McKesson, the nation’s largest drug distributor, will be grilled about executive pay and controlled substances at its annual meeting on Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: The immense pay packages bestowed on corporate chieftains are often said to reflect feats of management that enrich company shareholders. An executive’s masterly performance justifies the compensation, in other words.

articles.headline: Abuses Hide in the Silence of Nondisparagement Agreements
articles.snippet: Often used at tech companies, nondisparagement agreements are increasingly included in employment contracts and legal settlements.
articles.abstract: Often used at tech companies, nondisparagement agreements are increasingly included in employment contracts and legal settlements.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Last October, AngelList, a company that helps tech start-ups raise money and hire employees, held an office retreat. In the Hollywood Hills, far from Silicon Valley, the firm’s mostly male staff mingled poolside with bikini-clad women who had been invited to the event.

articles.headline: Polish Parliament Approves Law Curtailing Courts’ Independence
articles.snippet: The measure, which the president is expected to sign, would allow the governing Law and Justice party to handpick Supreme Court justices.
articles.abstract: The measure, which the president is expected to sign, would allow the governing Law and Justice party to handpick Supreme Court justices.
articles.lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Brushing aside warnings from the European Union and ignoring tens of thousands of protesters in the streets, Poland’s Parliament gave final approval to a landmark measure on Saturday that would restructure the Supreme Court, putting it under effective control of the governing party.

articles.headline: Stakes for Exxon in Sanctions Case Go Far Beyond a $2 Million Fine
articles.snippet: The oil company, punished for violating sanctions against Russia, is fighting a wider threat to its reputation and the possibility of other sanctions to come.
articles.abstract: The oil company, punished for violating sanctions against Russia, is fighting a wider threat to its reputation and the possibility of other sanctions to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The $2 million fine that the Treasury Department levied on Exxon Mobil this week for violating sanctions against Russia is just a sliver of the oil company’s $7.8 billion in profit last year. But Exxon has decided nonetheless to wage a legal battle — one that could make President Trump’s cabinet meetings decidedly awkward.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: The Latest Voice at the Lectern: An Effusive New Yorker
articles.snippet: Anthony Scaramucci’s smooth style will be a distinct contrast with the southern drawl and sharp edges of Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the new press secretary.
articles.abstract: Anthony Scaramucci’s smooth style will be a distinct contrast with the southern drawl and sharp edges of Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the new press secretary.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the newly minted White House press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders spent most of her first briefing on Friday standing off to the side. Anthony Scaramucci, the just-named communications director, was dominating the lectern that Ms. Sanders had inherited only hours earlier, professing his love — 20 times — for President Trump and his administration.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Giants Confront New Walls in China
articles.snippet: The recent struggles of Apple, LinkedIn and Facebook show why the number of tech companies willing to have a try in China is dwindling.
articles.abstract: The recent struggles of Apple, LinkedIn and Facebook show why the number of tech companies willing to have a try in China is dwindling.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Facebook is the world’s largest social network, with more than two billion users. LinkedIn was sold to Microsoft for $26 billion last year. And Apple is Apple, the most valuable company in the world.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Carolyn Zhang

articles.headline: One Family, Many Revolutions: From Black Panthers, to Silicon Valley, to Trump
articles.snippet: Ben Horowitz is helping define the modern tech age. His father shaped the ’60s radical left — before taking a hard right turn. Family chats get interesting.
articles.abstract: Ben Horowitz is helping define the modern tech age. His father shaped the ’60s radical left — before taking a hard right turn. Family chats get interesting.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMARILLO, Calif. — For generations, the Horowitz family has cheered on the revolution.

articles.headline: One by One, Marry-Your-Rapist Laws Are Falling in the Middle East
articles.snippet: Women’s rights groups are making bold efforts to change loopholes that allow accused and convicted rapists to evade punishment by marrying their victims.
articles.abstract: Women’s rights groups are making bold efforts to change loopholes that allow accused and convicted rapists to evade punishment by marrying their victims.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Gruesome billboards of a woman in a bloodied and torn bridal gown appeared around Beirut recently, captioned in Arabic: “A white dress doesn’t cover up rape.” This spring, a women’s rights group, Abaad, hung similarly defiled gowns along the city’s famous seaside promenade.

articles.headline: Turkey Sees Foes at Work in Gold Mines, Cafes and ‘Smurf Village’
articles.snippet: The government has seized more than 950 companies, from a baklava chain to a major construction firm, over suspected ties to a coup attempt last year.
articles.abstract: The government has seized more than 950 companies, from a baklava chain to a major construction firm, over suspected ties to a coup attempt last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Akin Ipek, one of Turkey’s richest men, was staying in the Park Tower Hotel in London when the police raided his television network in Istanbul. The raid was national news, so Mr. Ipek opened his laptop and watched an unnerving spectacle: an attack on his multibillion-dollar empire, in real time.

articles.headline: In Minneapolis, Unusual Police Killing Raises an Old Outcry: Why?
articles.snippet: The fatal shooting of Justine Damond had uncommon circumstances and stirred an uproar in Australia, but once more there were blanks to fill in.
articles.abstract: The fatal shooting of Justine Damond had uncommon circumstances and stirred an uproar in Australia, but once more there were blanks to fill in.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — There was something bad going on in the alleyway behind the house, she told her fiancé on the phone, someone who sounded as if she was in distress, maybe a rape. It was past 11 p.m., and most people on Washburn Avenue were furled in their beds.
articles.byline: By John Eligon, Vivian Yee and Matt Furber

articles.headline: Congress Reaches Deal on Russia Sanctions, Setting Up Tough Choice for Trump
articles.snippet: White House officials acknowledge that the president would all but have to sign legislation punishing Russia for its election interference.
articles.abstract: White House officials acknowledge that the president would all but have to sign legislation punishing Russia for its election interference.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional leaders have reached an agreement on sweeping sanctions legislation to punish Russia for its election meddling and aggression toward its neighbors, they said Saturday, defying the White House’s argument that President Trump needs flexibility to adjust the sanctions to fit his diplomatic initiatives with Moscow.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Trump’s ‘Great National Infrastructure Program’? Stalled
articles.snippet: Everyone agrees that America’s bridges, roadways and waterworks are in bad need of repair. But the president has yet to deliver on his promised plan.
articles.abstract: Everyone agrees that America’s bridges, roadways and waterworks are in bad need of repair. But the president has yet to deliver on his promised plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a candidate, President Trump billed himself as a new breed of think-big Republican, pitching a $1 trillion campaign pledge to reconstruct the nation’s roadways, waterworks and bridges — along with a promise to revive the lost art of the bipartisan deal.

articles.headline: White House Signals Acceptance of Russia Sanctions Bill
articles.snippet: President Trump expressed anger at Republicans who abandoned him on the legislation and forced his hand.
articles.abstract: President Trump expressed anger at Republicans who abandoned him on the legislation and forced his hand.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House indicated on Sunday that President Trump would accept new legislation curtailing his authority to lift sanctions on Russia on his own, a striking turnaround after a broad revolt by lawmakers of both parties who distrusted his friendly approach to Moscow and sought to tie his hands.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Andrew Higgins

articles.headline: At Chicago Sun-Times, New Owners Vow Return to Paper’s Working-Class Roots
articles.snippet: Despite the pledge, some in the nation’s third-largest city worry that The Sun-Times, now partly owned by trade unions, will veer from its tradition of covering them aggressively.
articles.abstract: Despite the pledge, some in the nation’s third-largest city worry that The Sun-Times, now partly owned by trade unions, will veer from its tradition of covering them aggressively.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — At a Christmas party in December, Edwin Eisendrath, a former Chicago alderman, bumped into Jorge Ramirez, a labor leader. As guests nibbled on decadent desserts, the two men contemplated an audacious plan.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: In China, Herd of ‘Gray Rhinos’ Threatens Economy
articles.snippet: Several Chinese conglomerates are now so big, so complex and so indebted that the government is trying to bring them to heel.
articles.abstract: Several Chinese conglomerates are now so big, so complex and so indebted that the government is trying to bring them to heel.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Let the West worry about so-called black swans, rare and unexpected events that can upset financial markets. China is more concerned about “gray rhinos” — large and visible problems in the economy that are ignored until they start moving fast.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Sui-Lee Wee

articles.headline: If GoDaddy Can Turn the Corner on Sexism, Who Can’t?
articles.snippet: Skeptics scoffed when Blake Irving vowed to reform the internet business built on salacious television ads. But the change is looking real.
articles.abstract: Skeptics scoffed when Blake Irving vowed to reform the internet business built on salacious television ads. But the change is looking real.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few years after Blake Irving became chief executive of the internet company GoDaddy, he spoke at a conference where the jeers started almost immediately.

articles.headline: U.S. Foresaw Better Return in Seizing Fannie and Freddie Profits
articles.snippet: Documents show that officials, citing a need to protect against losses, actually expected to generate more money for the Treasury. Shareholders say they were wronged.
articles.abstract: Documents show that officials, citing a need to protect against losses, actually expected to generate more money for the Treasury. Shareholders say they were wronged.
articles.lead_paragraph: In August 2012, the federal government abruptly changed the terms of the bailout provided to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the mortgage finance giants that had been devastated by the financial crisis. Instead of continuing to receive payments on the taxpayer assistance, Treasury officials decided to begin seizing all the profits both companies generated every quarter.

articles.headline: Leader Who Rebuilt Time Warner Empire Prepares an Exit
articles.snippet: Jeffrey Bewkes, a quiet defender of CNN who has delivered Time Warner high returns, plans to leave the company if a merger with AT&T is approved.
articles.abstract: Jeffrey Bewkes, a quiet defender of CNN who has delivered Time Warner high returns, plans to leave the company if a merger with AT&T is approved.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeffrey L. Bewkes championed acclaimed series like “The Sopranos” and “Sex and the City” at HBO, salvaged Time Warner from its disastrous merger with AOL and publicly battled his rival media mogul Rupert Murdoch three years ago to fend off a hostile takeover.

articles.headline: President Bachelet of Chile Is the Last Woman Standing in the Americas
articles.snippet: It seems nearly certain that soon only men will lead governments in the Americas, underscoring the elusive quest for gender parity in politics.
articles.abstract: It seems nearly certain that soon only men will lead governments in the Americas, underscoring the elusive quest for gender parity in politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — No one relished the milestone more than President Michelle Bachelet of Chile.

articles.headline: Poland’s President Vetoes 2 Proposed Laws Limiting Courts’ Independence
articles.snippet: The decision was a setback for the governing party, though a bill giving it more control over local courts was still set for approval.
articles.abstract: The decision was a setback for the governing party, though a bill giving it more control over local courts was still set for approval.
articles.lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Andrzej Duda was a relatively obscure member of the right-wing Law and Justice party when the leader of the party and the most powerful man in the country plucked him from the chorus line to become its candidate for president in 2015. For most of the party’s first 20 months in power, he was a reliable proponent of the governing party’s nationalist initiatives.

articles.headline: U.S. Inflation Remains Low, and That’s a Problem
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve is struggling to hit its annual inflation target for the sixth straight year, suggesting that, once again, it may be too optimistic about the health of the economy.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve is struggling to hit its annual inflation target for the sixth straight year, suggesting that, once again, it may be too optimistic about the health of the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States has a problem: not enough inflation.

articles.headline: ‘I Did Not Collude,’ Kushner Says After Meeting Senate Investigators
articles.snippet: Jared Kushner’s rare public comments about Russia were an attempt to steer the White House through a political storm. But they carried legal risk.
articles.abstract: Jared Kushner’s rare public comments about Russia were an attempt to steer the White House through a political storm. But they carried legal risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s son-in-law, Jared Kushner, described himself to Senate investigators on Monday as a political and foreign policy neophyte who met with Russians as part of a hectic and unconventional presidential campaign, not as part of a plot to steer the election.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Greece Looks to Turn a Corner After Years of Economic Pain
articles.snippet: The announcement that Athens would issue new bonds offered hope that one of Europe’s weakest economies might at last be weaning itself off international bailouts.
articles.abstract: The announcement that Athens would issue new bonds offered hope that one of Europe’s weakest economies might at last be weaning itself off international bailouts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Greece, long Europe’s economic problem child, is trying to prove that it has made progress in its recovery efforts by announcing plans to sell debt for the first time in years.

articles.headline: In San Antonio Smuggling Case, a Fatal Journey in a Packed and Sweltering Truck
articles.snippet: Descriptions of the immigrants’ journey, which became one of the nation’s deadliest human trafficking episodes, were revealed in a criminal complaint.
articles.abstract: Descriptions of the immigrants’ journey, which became one of the nation’s deadliest human trafficking episodes, were revealed in a criminal complaint.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — When the smugglers first closed the door of the truck’s trailer, it was pitch black inside.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez, Richard Pérez-Peña and David Montgomery
